The EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) is a ‘cap and trade’ system covering the power sector, energy-intensive industries and all airlines operating in Europe (European or not). The public authority sets a greenhouse gas (GHG) emission cap, and installations covered by the EU ETS use allowances to ensure that their carbon emissions comply with this cap. Allowances are either freely allocated or allocated through auctioning by the public authority. Revenues generated from auctioning EU ETS allowances are an increasing source of income for Member States. 

Member States must use at least 50% of auctioning revenues for climate- and energy-related purposes under National Grant Schemes, such as GHG emission mitigation; climate change adaptation; research and development projects; renewable energy development; transitioning to a low-carbon economy; preventing deforestation; and improving energy efficiency.
